user_message:
An agent A claimed that the following metal_uio_dev_dma_unmap code violates the MISRA C 2023 rule 2.2.
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<target_code>
Here is the original code of metal_uio_dev_dma_unmap.
```c
static void metal_uio_dev_dma_unmap(struct linux_bus *lbus,
				    struct linux_device *ldev,
				    uint32_t dir,
				    struct metal_sg *sg,
				    int nents)
{
	(void) lbus;
	(void) ldev;
	(void) dir;
	(void) sg;
	(void) nents;
}
```
</target_code>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- explanation: your evaluation of the scenario provided by the agent A.
- is_report_correct: whether the report is correct or not (true/false). True means there is a violation.
</response format>
<scenario>
The agent A provided the following violation scenario:
The function metal_uio_dev_dma_unmap has a body that only contains (void) casts of its parameters. Those casts are no-op operations whose removal would not affect program behaviour, so they constitute dead code under MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2. In other words, the entire function body is dead code (an empty stub); either implement the required behavior or remove the unused parameters and/or the function to comply with the rule.
</scenario>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_uio_dev_dma_unmap:
struct metal_sg {
	void *virt; /**< CPU virtual address */
	struct metal_io_region *io; /**< IO region */
	int len; /**< length */
}
</additional code>

<instruction>
Judge whether the report is correct or not.
</instruction>
explanation: The (void) parameter-cast statements in the function body are no-op operations that are executed when the function is called but have no effect on program state. Per MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 (“Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code”), those statements qualify as dead code. (Only the case where their presence is relied on for timing would change that conclusion, but there is no indication of such a requirement here.) To avoid the issue either implement the required behavior, remove the unused parameters from the function (omit the parameter names in the definition), or otherwise document the intentionally empty implementation in a way acceptable to your coding standard.
